name: Former Employee of Landlord
short_description: Dwelling let to employee, employment has ended

employment_letting.original_letting: Dwelling let to tenant as consequence of employment
employment_letting.employer: By landlord seeking possession or former landlord

employer_need.requirement: Landlord reasonably requires dwelling for another employee
employer_need.or: For self to live in relation to employment

evidence_required: Tenancy agreement showing let as consequence of employment
Evidence of employment cessation (resignation letter, dismissal notice, retirement)
Evidence of need for new employee (job posting, contract)
New employee's details and start date
Statement explaining need for accommodation for new employee

employment_letting_types.key_factor: Accommodation essential to employment, not just benefit

high_probability: Clear employment contract linking accommodation to job
Genuine need for accommodation for new employee
New employee identified and starting soon
medium_probability: Employment link clear but new need less urgent
New employee not yet hired but role advertised
Accommodation useful but not essential for new role
low_probability: Weak link between accommodation and employment
No genuine need for new employee
Accommodation not essential to any role
Alternative accommodation available for new employee

red_flags: Accommodation not mentioned in employment contract
Employment link is weak or incidental
Landlord has other accommodation for new employee
Tenant never actually worked for landlord
tenant_defenses: Accommodation not let as consequence of employment
No genuine need for new employee
Landlord has no current employment business
Tenant has nowhere else to go and new employee not imminent
notes: Ground 16 is DISCRETIONARY and rarely used. Requires clear link between accommodation and employment. Court considers reasonableness including tenant's circumstances and genuine need for new employee. Common in agriculture, hospitality, education sectors.
case_law: Elvidge v Coventry CC [2000] - Must show accommodation let for better performance of duties
Royal Philanthropic Society v County [1985] - Link between accommodation and employment essential
Skinner v Geary [1931] - Employment must be reason for letting
court_considerations: Was accommodation let as consequence of employment?
Is there genuine need for accommodation for new employee?
Is new employee identified and starting?
Is accommodation essential for the new role?

employment_cessation.dismissal: Clear cessation (but unfair dismissal may affect reasonableness)

service_occupancy.definition: Occupier is still employee and has service occupancy license (not tenancy)
service_occupancy.possession: Simpler process if license not tenancy
service_occupancy.key_difference: Ground 16 for tenancies; license claims are not under Housing Act
